comments.text: Pretty cool - I'm printing it now. It's worth mentioning that the "thumbrest" by the word Holoped is the only part that actually touches the print bed. My printer had some issues running at 0.2mm layer height where the first layer was nonexistent on the majority of the part, and the skirt was placed under the piece. It looks to be healing itself pretty well, but larger layer heights are probably recommended.

Too lazy to get off the couch while binge-watching streaming television? Overwhelmed amateur bartender at a get together? Turn these minor annoyances into a thrilling, topsy-turvy adventure as a Sphero robot attempts to deliver frosty beverages to you or your guests! This first draft attempt at a cold one delivery vehicle is still a work-in-progress - find out more below in the notes on design and stability - improvements coming for v2. Sphero harness remixed from rmorrill's Sphero Rig art bot: https://www.tinkercad.com/things/enCZyzqszwN-sphero-rig

Printer Brand:

Printrbot

Printer:

Simple Black

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.3

Infill:

10%

Notes: I used a raft for my base for extra mitigation of warping - it may not be necessary on your printer or with a heated bed!

Assembly I found a set of 3.5 mm Traxxas smooth rods and c-clips at a nearby electronics box store. I used these to assemble the wheels, which are just held in so far by the snugness of the fit. The wheel holes might be a bit small with their current diameter and the tolerance was a bit inconsistent due to warping, so a little filing might be in order to get things rolling. I would also recommend cutting out and gluing thin strips of felt on the underside of the harness to prevent your Sphero from getting too scratched up.

Design and Stability Notes For this design, I borrowed the harness and rear connector from rmorrill's Sphero Rig art bot: https://www.tinkercad.com/things/enCZyzqszwN-sphero-rig I designed the drink holder section and combined everything in TinkerCAD. I also designed the wheels in TinkerCAD, but if you wanted something generic and less lovey-dovey (this robot had a specific Valentine's Day application) then rmorrill posted wheels for the art bot: https://www.tinkercad.com/things/2M3DjmRev33-sphero-rig-wheel For the next iteration, I will be looking into ways to reduce the weight of the cart and move the axles back to stabilize the cart, which carries cans pretty competently but struggles with a full 341 ml bottle depending on floor surface. It delivers chocolate bars to surprised colleagues very capably. A friend and colleague also suggested re-designing a way to pin the wheels in underneath - so I will be looking at that also for the next re-design to again improve stability and minimize spills! This was my first time trying to design a moving assembly and it was a great learning experience.

This little mount glues to the back of a smartphone case and allows it to mount on a standard tripod. (The pictured tripod is one for motion pictures.) Instructions:
The mount requires a case with a flat back and edge, such as one downloaded for your model phone on Thingiverse or sold on the web for as little as 99¢. Glue the mount to the back of the case flush with the bottom edge (get a hard case; silicone cases won’t successfully glue). There’s a recess on the bottom edge that allows for the raised border sometimes found on the commercial cases. It also requires a 1/4” - 20 thread machine nut that fits a standard tripod screw mount. The nut is a tight fit in the hex recess and if you can’t push it into its space, try inserting a bolt through the hole from below, threading the nut onto it, and pulling it in (this insures that it goes in squarely). If your machine produces a print with too tight a fit, increase the size of the print by a percent or two. The only critical size is of the recess for the nut, and a loose fit can be glued in if needed. Place the phone into the case before bolting it to the tripod, and happy snapping!

title: Arch LED light bulb assembly jig

description.text:
A quick test made in Sketch-Up for an Idea I've had.
What if instead making the LEDs in an LED light bulb shine out only the front, they could form the shape of the entire bulb? Make six or more arches and assemble them in a light bulb shape.
The holes are intended to hold the LEDs while soldering them together in strings, and then allow the finished string to be lifted out easily. 
The holes are 5mm in diameter in the model but I recommend scaling up the model by 5% to 10% before printing for a better fit if your printer won't produce 100% accurate parts.
I printed one at 110%, but I haven't assembled an LED bulb yet.

I was having trouble with a some 200g filament I ordered for $5.  The spool it shipped on was too flimsy to print from.  I didn't want to re-spool each role of 200g so I designed a spool to fit over their shipping spool to make it stronger and allow me to change the spool I am using without having to re-spool them. The two parts of my spool screw together and clamp the flimsy spool securely.  I really like being able to buy smaller amounts of filament and this spool make them easier to use.  I added a hole on one side to allow for re-spooling.
This is my first design on thingiverse so any feedback is good.Thank you.
Edit Notes: the chamfer was blocking the threading on the first male spool half. it has been removed and replaced.

comments.text: the male half suffers from an incredibly thin wall on the threaded section and may be difficult to print. I had a failure at 100% scale but was successful at 110%

comments.text: The issue with the male post (as can be seen in many of the makes), is likely due to the thickness on the most inner part of the threading. I played with various settings in Simplify 3D and the problem seems to be coming from the extrusion width. By default many slicers, such as S3D, will set extrusion width to 120% (.48mm in my case), causing the final sliced model to have gaps all around the sides. If you lower the width to something closer to the stock, the holes will start filling up. In my case, I wanted to make sure the walls were solid so I simply printed the thicker remixed version instead. Despite this issue, its still a pretty nice design and works perfectly for those $5 spools (like ProtoParadigm for example). Other than this, my only thought was there could have been some fillets thrown on the edges to make it look nicer, and also work better for rolling bearing-based spool holders like mine.

comments.text: Unfortunately, the STL file format does not, of itself, have dimensions. The binary STL format, which is what most modeling software produces (there is an ASCII format, but for anything other than simple test models, it creates huge files, so it's rarely used except for testing new interfaces), has an 80-character field at the start of the file, and then is binary vertex, normal, and attribute data; there are no units associated with the vertex data unless someone has an implementation-specific use of the 80-character header field. From the technical description of the STL file format on fabbers.com:

description.text:
I was having problems with the corners of ABS prints adhering until I tried blocking the cold drafts in my print room from the bed of the printer. So I made three of these brackets, popped them into the vertical rails of my Rostock Mac V2 printer, then cut three pieces of poster board to go between them. No more problems with corners adhering to the bed! In addition, I've noticed that the bed heats a little faster and the temp seems to stay a little more stable.
The poster board pieces I cut were 14-3/4" x 5". Make them too tall and they'll interfere with the arms of the printer.
I made these from ABS. PLA was too brittle to spring the arms open around the vertical rails. The whole system is easy to install or remove in about a minute, and the poster board slips right out for removing your parts or cleaning the bed.

description.text: This is for up-cycling leftover plastic microwavable food containers into a stackable drawer system. It is a big, challenging print, filling up nearly the entire build volume of our 300x200x200 mm ExtraBot 3020 E3D printer. (http://extrabot.net/index.php/product/14-extrabot-3020a-e3d) It works very well and we've included the SketchUp 16 file for anyone who would like to modify it. The bottom braces are a bit fragile so they might be updated in future version. A Customizer version would also be nice. This project shows you how to use 3D printing together with reusing existing material and opens up a lot of new possibilities. If you print one out, please share some photos. We love to see people make our designs.

description.text: Careful with this.. it's the Internet. As seen in this scene from UK sitcom The IT Crowd in which a pair of mischievous IT workers play a prank on their tech-illiterate manager. 3D printing is really not the best way to build a full-size working replica of the prop, as the original was made with cheap off-the-shelf parts and there's already a great Instructable with all the info you need to build your own. Though this copy is modelled at full-size, I imagine it being much more useful for scaling down and printing as a desk toy or prop for action figures, dioramas, and such. The ones in my photos are printed at 1:6 and 1:12 scale. This model is primarily based on measurements gleaned from that Instructable, many thanks to author Melty Mcface for doing the work.
There's a complete STL ready for scaling, printing, and painting, as well as a version without the simulated "LED" in case you'd rather stick a craft jewel or something on for looks.

description.text: The design contained here is a Delta 3D printer. Let me start by saying this will seem quite overwhelming. However, my hope is that after you review this content you'll come to the conclusion that it is achievable. Many of the things I describe below are outlined in this video, though reviewing the text herein will certainly be beneficial!

The Inspiration One day I decided I wanted to build a robot. So I bought motors, motor controllers, and I planned to make a car or something. But then I realized I had no structure! So I went to LEGO stores looking for "universal kits" and I couldn't really find anything (except for perhaps their MindStorm). So, I decided to use the parts I bought and build a 3D printer... this way I could just print the parts I wanted. After I decided to build a printer, and I did a little research on the internet, the idea got started with me designing the End Effector mount in Microsoft PowerPoint... yes, I said PowerPoint. Once the PowerPoint concept was done (painfully) I decided to switch to a legitimate CAD program, and I jumped over to FreeCAD. PowerPoint End Effector design (note: I ended up going 75% scale of this in the final design). FreeCAD End Effector design Overall Design So now that I have an End Effector... lets design a printer! First lets take a look at the overall design. Then I'll break down how I got here. If you look at the problem as a whole, it looks rather overwhelming. However, like any math problem, if you break it up into bite-sized parts... it's actually manageable. So here I show you the full Delta 3D Printer... but I'll next show you some bite-sized pieces. (The full design is also included in the files, where each piece can be extracted.) Also shown in the design is my Mark II. The full Delta 3D Printer The Delta 3D Printer in action The 95% solution of the Delta 3D Printer in CAD The Base First lets start with the base. Lets be honest, after a week of CAD class you should be able to design that base. There are only a few holes to support the vertical structure, and the overall shape is pretty simple after you've taken geometry. The physical base (along with the middle and top section) on my Delta 3D Printer was made out of 6061-T6 aluminum cut on a friends CNC machine. However, this is just because I wanted an all metal 3D printer. Once this design is locked down (and you see how simple it is), this could be cut out of wood, MDF, etc. Metal was just my design choice (for stability, longevity, and cool-factor!) Bottom plate of printer The Top Next lets look at the top. Lets be honest, after a week of CAD class you should be able to design that top. There are only a few holes to support the vertical structure, and the overall shape is pretty simple after you've taken geometry. (Yes I'm repeating myself on purpose!) Same notes as above about the physical structure. Top plate of printer The Middle Ok... I won't say it a third time. Yes, the middle plate must be designed more diligently (to place all of that support structure, motor mounts, heated bed mounts, etc). However, everything said above still holds true! Middle plate of printer So what's next Well... the hard part of the design is over! Really planning the layout of those plates is the "hard" part. All of the vertical structure I bought from a vendor (MakeBlock). Now, as I said above regarding using 6061 for the plates... you don't need to use a specific vendor or metal vertical structure. I just went with this vendor because they had dimensions listed and I could build to them. What you need to do is either design all of these parts, and cut them yourself... or use a vendor. I decided that for the "trivial" pieces, I'd use a vendor. Example 1: Vertical Support Example 2: Motor Mount Parts List So once the plates were designed, all of the vertical support and other parts were purchased. Metal Parts:
  • 2 x MakeBlock Beam0824-496-Blue (6-Pack)
  • 3 x MakeBlock Beam0824-112-Blue (4-Pack)
  • 6 x MakeBlock Beam0824-048-Blue (4-Pack)
  • 6 x MakeBlock Linear Motion Shaft D8x496mm
  • 4 x MakeBlock 42BYG Stepper Motor Bracket-Blue
    • Brains:
  • 1 x BeagleBone Black (computer)
  • 1 x BeBoPr++ Controller
  • 3 x Endstop Switch (I used mechanical not optical)
    • I used a BeagleBone Black because I had one laying around my house. A board to drive the motors was attached (the BeBoPr++). The benefit of this setup is dedicated hardware to drive the motors, and the fact that I could run LinuxCNC an open-source CNC program. Other brains could have been used (like a SmoothieBoard or a Raspberry Pi) and more traditional software to drive it. You really just need to choose what you're comfortable with! I chose a route that was a bit challenging... however, it can handle doing complex delta control without ever bogging down, even at high speeds. Mech/Elec Motion:
  • 12 x 3D Printed End Cap (STL file included)
  • 1-2 x Carbon Fiber Rod (cut to length for 3 arms)
  • 3 x MakeBlock Linear Motion Slide Unit 8mm (Pair)
  • 4 x Nema17 Stepper Motor
  • 4 x DRV8825 Motor Controller
  • 1 x SeeMeCNC EZStruder Extruder
  • 1 x GT2 Pulley Set (3 idlers and 3 pulleys)
  • 3 x GT2 Cable
  • 12 x Neodymium Magnet 1/4" x 1/4"
  • 12 x Ball Joint
    • Most of these parts will be obvious from the pictures I provide. Their placement is rather self explanatory. I literally placed these based on intuition... and it worked out well. Nuts & Bolts:
  • Lots x Socket Cap Screw M4x##
  • Lots x Nut 4mm
    • Other:
  • 1 x 12V ~30A Power Supply (if using heated bed need high amps)
  • 1 x Heated Bed (if desired)
  • 1 x Hot End
  • 1 x Build Plate
    • Optional:
  • 1 x MakeBlock Cuttable Linkage-Blue (10-Pack) [to mount stuff]
  • 3 x MakeBlock Beam0824-096-Blue (4-Pack) [to make it taller]
  • 6 x MakeBlock Shaft D8×96mm-H [to make it taller]
  • 3 x PolyCarbonate Sheet [to enclose the chamber]
    • Photographic Assistance The arms holding the End Effector to the Sliders (design not provided... I have to leave something for you!) Closeup of End Effector. Here I'm holding the B3 Innovations Pico Hot End. However, you can use any hot end you want (like E3D)! The enclosed magnet (STL included) The microswitch for an upper limit, shown with an idler and GT2 belt. The extruder mounted to the side, feeding the Bowden setup. The electronics. (Note: The motors have heat-sinks and fans on them. This is optional.) It won't be problem free You may have noticed that in the original design (PowerPoint) the End Effector was bent down 30 degrees. Well... bending the part after CNC didn't quite work well. The final design did not have that bend. You will have problems; fight through them! ... it shouldn't be rocking There will be a reward for your hard work Once you diligently work through the design, and the weeks/months of building... these are results you could have! Precision parts
    My lithophane lamp
    My ez-spin motor
    My quadcopter 30.23mm for a 30.00mm calibration cube (and that's including first layer buldging) My lithophane lamp My ez-spin motor My quad-copter frame

Objective This is a project to create a tool. The 3D printer in and of itself, while enjoyable to watch, is simply a tool. The 3D printer (be it my printer [which I nicknamed the BraggBot], a MakerBot, etc) is just a very technical hammer. This is not a project about making a revolutionary 3D printer, rather, you must use this tool to come up with your revolutionary idea! Audience This project is best suited for high school aged people and beyond. This project can be accomplished by one person, or even by a team. Preparation This project can be completed after taking perhaps 2 quarters of High School Computer Aided Drafting (CAD). I took AutoCAD in high school in 1999 and 2000 (2 quarters). I completed this project based on that experience. My engineering degrees only gave me confidence to complete this task. Though, I must admit, it also helps to be a bit nerdy and generally computer literate. Also, one of the first required decisions is a material choice (aluminum, MDF, etc). This will help to solidify the budget. Steps Steps to creating this are essentially defined already in the "How I designed this" section. Just start with one piece... the end effector, the base, the sliders... pick something. Draw that in CAD, look at it, be proud of the piece. Then start with another piece (same thing), look at it, be proud of the piece. After you and/or your team has designed all the pieces - put them together. You'll be amazed how simple something can be if you break it down into it's constitute components. Results Once you've completed this project, you should be able to 3D print effectively anything on Thingiverse or from CAD. So this is a great moment to thank the people who (1) host this site and (2) offer the opportunity for nerds like me to share. My printer is not for sale, I only made one of them, and I'm not looking to make any money. The MakerBot is a beautiful printer, and perhaps for most people it is best. However, for the die-hard nerds out there (or team of minor nerds which add up to a die-hard nerd)... this is perhaps a challenge for you.

My name is Charlie Burgan. I am 12 years old and from a student's point of view, a teacher doing a lesson with 3D printed dice would be pretty cool. I decided to create and easy to read die for the MakerEd Project. This die features six sides and full numbers instead of dots.

Printer:

Micro 3D

Rafts:

Yes

Supports:

No

Notes: If you don't use raft the side that is touching the print bed will be weighted so it will almost always land on a certain number. you have to use raft to prevent it.

How I Designed It The software I used was Tinkercad. First, I started off with a basic cube. I set numbers 1-6 on the plate. I raised them to a height of 16mm because that was the height of the cube. I took each number and placed them in the middle of each side of the die. Then I made them all into holes. I clicked group to make it all solid, and then I was finished. Or so I thought.... I ended up having to scale it up to 20mm to make it easy to read. That is also why I used numbers instead of holes; it would make it easy to read.

Objectives Students will be expected to learn how to work together. They will use these dice to play teamwork styled board-games. The students will learn how to cooperate together. Audiences 1st through 3rd grade students would be doing this project. It is important for kids to learn how to work together and cooperate early on. It is a great life skill to have, and is used in many careers. Preparation The only materials students will need is the teamwork board-games. No other materials are unnecessary. Steps 1: Find a teamwork board-game that is set for ages 7-10. This board-game must use dice. 2: Instead of using the regular dice, replace them with the new easy to read dice. 3: Explain to the students how to play the game. 4: While they are playing, walk around to see if everything is going smoothly. 5: Watch and see the smile on their faces as they learn how to work together. Results At the end of the project, students should have learned how to cooperate with one another. They also should have learned how to work together to achieve a common goal. Theese skills are necessary for a good career later in life.
This is a stand for a 22mm vapor cigarette, for best results put a piece of velcro on the back of the stand and attach it to another piece of velcro you have put on whatever you want it to hang on

I thing I'm getting older, but having good lighting while drilling holes in my PCBs is more and more a good thing to have. ;-) So I created this.

Scale if needed, depends on how your printer is set up. Probably needs drilling at 5mm holes for the LEDs, but you will see after printing. 
It just needs a little bit of force putting on the big nut at the bottom.

remixed_from.title: SkyFi adapter for CGEM DX Tripod

title: SkyFi adapter for Orion Atlas EQ-G/Sky Watcher EQ-6 mount

description.text:
I just loaded taggartbros' CGEM DX (nice mount!) adapter into 123d Design and remade the part that "clips" to the tripod leg.  The EQ-G/EQ-6 tripod legs are 2 inch/50 mm, so this will fit ANY tripod that has the same size legs ie. Celestron CPC.
I printing this part in ABS and with the shrinkage, my holder "snapped" onto the leg.  If you print in PLA, the fit may be a little looser, so you will probably need the Velcro (hook and loop) cable wrap.  My tripod does not have the leg straps, so I used the Velcro tape as insurance that the SkyFi adapter did not fall off the leg when I use the hand controller.

This is a customizable clip based on my snap-in flashlight clip. It allows you to attach a small flashlight to your hardhat to use as a head lamp. Two screws clamp the clip securely to the brim of a hardhat. Not all hardhats have the accessory slots, so I made this one so my slot-less brethren will still be able to see the light.

-Measure diameter of flashlight  
-Customize by editing scad or use customizer (though I was having trouble with the customizer lately, previews weren't showing and generates an error when creating new thing. If you're having problems, edit the scad)  
-Print out using 100% infill.   
-I used 8-32 nuts and 1/2" long 8-32 machine screws, but you can change the size of the nut traps and holes in the scad.  
-Clamp to hardhat, and snap in your flashlight!  
The included STL fits my Sipik SK-68 clone, and mounts to many different hard hat models.

Here is a hot end idea I have had for the Geeetech G2s, I have made it up and attached a fan to it and its printing very well. It utilises the Micro-Swiss MakerBot Replicator Nozzle & Thermal Tube upgrade and a genuine E3D heater block kit. You will need to drill and tap two extra holes to fit on a 25x25mm fan for cooling. http://www.micro-swiss.com/#!product-page/cv9c/996f53f1-21c4-3150-19aa-909d18850eef http://e3d-online.com/E3D-v6/Spares/v6-Heater-Block-and-Fixings Update: Feb 29th 2016, I have successfully printed Colorfabb XT at 260 degrees on the Geeetech G2S with no issues.

author: wlade

description.text:
This is a two part version of the Human Brain by jmil  
It requires no support so is easier to print and looks cool when you pull it apart front of someone.  
This was one of the most tricky things I have ever printed - good luck.  
If anyone with an Ultimaker fancies a challenge, print this.  
It's printed with Faberdashery Pink PLA.

You need at least 8% infill to print this, you can go higher, it will use a lot of plastic to print this brain and take a long time.  
It was printed with a standard 0.5mm nozzle and 0.3mm layer slice.  
The Gcode will be big 30MB+ for each part so really you want to be printing this from a SD card not via a serial connection.  
Each half was about 8 hours for me to print on a Prusa with heated bed.  
I also found a small slow moving fan blowing across the object really helps with this sort of build, it's just full of overhangs and thin plastic sections floating in the air.  Just make sure you don't over-cool your heated bed or hot-end if you do decide to use a fan.

remixed_from.title: Extruder stepper mount for standard Prusa i3 x-carriage

description.text:
This is a clamping NEMA 17 stepper mount for 2020 rail.
I'm using this to hold my bowden extruder.
It's a remix of the stepper mount by AndrewBCN in thing #528934, which is a also a remix. It requires:
one M3 20mm bolt and nut to tighten the clamp
one M5 16mm bolt for the 2020 rail mount
one M5 T-slot nut OpenSCAD source file is included with proper attribution to paenian for his great original design. Update: Version 2B has the correct spacing between the clamp and the block that fits in the 2020 extrusion.

comments.text: So, I've printed out the X Carriage part of this and the tolerances are a little too tight, and it probably is on the other part too, can you loosen them some? the joint should be loose enough after some flexing so that it'll bend under the weight of several links. right now I have to force the joint to bend.

I printed a locomotive for my nephew when he turned two. His 4.5 year old sister asked what I brought for her. I told her that she was old enough to design her own toys if she wanted. She enthusiastically set to work with markers and scissors. Once we scanned the drawings into the computer I traced the drawings by hand in Inkscape and rendered them from DXF in openscad.
Sorry I didn't get a photo of the finished toys. When asked if she liked how they turned out she said "I love them."
Get someone young to design something and help them print it out.

remixed_from.author: misan
remixed_from.title: Greg's Wade extruder for Prusa i3

title: Greg's Wade extruder for Prusa i3 redux

description.text:
I like misan's modified Greg's for Prusa i3 (and Bob is my uncle), but I wanted a few small changes, starting with not having the head of the idler hinge bolt hit the X carriage (the newer one, as shown in the photo). Here's a list, in no particular order, of the changes I've made:
  • Set base extra depth to 2mm so the head of the idler hinge bolt doesn't interfere with the X carriage.
  • Added a small thumb-grip to the top of the idler.
  • Increased hole for 608 bearing from 22.3 to 23mm because they are always too tight.
  • The forward-foot of the base was shortened by 10mm. This also allows for fan mount to fit on standard x carriage (described below)
  • The legacy mounting holes were removed. I don't need them, and they encourage cracking of the base.
  • Added recessed M3 nut traps for JHead (wildseyed) mount on the X-carriage side of the body.
  • Radius of the nut trap built into the idler hinge was increased by .25mm because mine are always too small.
  • Added a OSH logo (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:27097) tucked into the space under the motor mount, which makes the extruder 18% more awesome and gaurantees your prints all come out better.
  • The thickness of the bearing washer was changed from 1mm to 3 times the layer_thickness.
  • I added a 40mm fan holder to the design. Because I made the foot of the extruder shorter, I can mount this to the spare hole of the X carriage, and it doesn't increase the width of the whole assembly at all. Also, it tilts which is nicer than mounting a 30mm fan straight to the extruder.
  • The radius of recessed carriage mounting holes was increased by .1mm so that M3 bolts go in nicer.
  • The beveled guide inside the idler was moved outward a little, because it's too tight.
  • The cutout for the 20mm idler bolt (M8) was increased in radius to M8/2.
    • There is also a separate openscad file and STL for a 30mm fan. The fan in that scad file is parametric, so you should be able to adjust it for other size fans also.
  • I have also uploaded a version of the base with the holes put back (sorry, can't fit the fan mount then but is needed for some types of hot-ends), and also a version of the idler with widened holes that work better for M4x60mm screws (easier to come by than M3x60mm)

author: plodder

description.text:
Need help troubleshooting your Teknikio circuit?
Want to test if a mystery material is conductive?
The Teknikio Continuity Test Tool is just what you need! You can use this simple tool to test your connections along the way as you build and design a Teknikio circuit with conductive tape!
  • The provided photo guide will walk you through the build process step-by-step!
  • You'll need the Teknikio Sparking Sense Set for this project.
    • Wow, life just got a little bit easier. :)
Designed by Macakcat

Printer Brand:

Ultimaker

Printer:

Ultimaker 2

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2 mm

Infill:

10%

Parts You'll Need All the parts you need are included in the Teknikio Sparking Sense Set!

Parts Needed:

  • 1 Buzzer
  • 2 Alligator Clips
  • 1 Coin Cell Battery
  • Conductive Tape

Part Files to Print:

  • "ContinuityTestToolBottom.STL"
  • "ContinuityTestToolTop.STL"

Tools for Assembly:

  • Scissors
Everything you need for this project is pictured here (except the 3V coin cell battery apparently!) The Buzzer
  • The buzzer has a positive leg and a negative leg. The positive leg is long and the negative leg is short.
  • In this photo, the positive leg is up top and the negative leg is down below.
    During this build, we'll need to keep track of which leg is the positive one!
    • The Buzzer, Up Close and Personal Step 1: Prepping the Buzzer
  • Carefully bend the legs as shown.
    • Prepping the Buzzer! Step 2: Test-Fitting the Buzzer and Proper Placement
  • Fit the buzzer in place with the positive leg towards the battery slot (towards the bottom)!
    • Make sure the long leg (positive)) of the buzzer is facing down towards the battery slot! Step 3: Laying Down the First Pieces of Conductive Tape
  • There are some shallow grooves in your printed piece for the tape to sit in. Use these grooves to help you line the tape up nicely.
  • Start be adding two pieces of tape just like in the photo!
  • Very Helpful Hint: Place the conductive tape first, then the buzzer, then add a second layer of conductive tape on top of the buzzer legs to sandwich the legs in place! This will guarantee a good connection here.
    • Adding the first pieces of conductive tape! Step 4: Laying Down the Conductive Tape (Continued)
  • Next step, add a little square of conductive tape in the upper left (see photo).
    • See the little piece of conductive tape in the upper left? Put some conductive tape right there! Step 5: Laying Down the Conductive Tape (Continued)
  • Now, add a little bit more conductive tape up top (see following photo).
  • Be sure the ends of this piece of conductive tape lay on top of the ends of the pieces we added earlier for a good connection.
    • Finishing up the negative side of our test tool! Step 6: Laying Down the Conductive Tape (Continued)
  • Along the right side, add a long strip of conductive tape.
  • Very Helpful Hint: The tape should extend past the shallow groove (near the bottom) by half a centimeter. This is critical to ensure the circuit is built correctly. Adding two layers of conductive tape here (one on top of the other) is a good idea too (you'll see why in the next step).
  • Be sure to lay down the conductive tape just like in the photo!
    • Adding a long piece of conductive tape! Step 7: Laying Down the Conductive Tape (Continued)
  • Now, working with the lid of the Continuity Test Tool, add the final piece of conductive tape as shown!
    • Laying down the final piece of conductive tape Step 8: Assembling the Pieces!
  • There are four pegs in the lid that need to fit into the four holes of the bottom printed part.
  • Line up the two pieces and carefully apply strong pressure at each of the four pegs to make a nice snap fit.
  • The lid should sit nice and flat on top of the bottom piece!
    • Finish up by assembling! Step 9: Putting in Your Battery
  • Be sure the positive (plus) side of the battery is facing down.
  • Slide the battery into the slot at the bottom of your Continuity Test Tool.
    • Insert the battery through the slot at the bottom (positive side faces down) Step 10: Attaching the Alligator Clips
  • Attach one alligator clip wire to the exposed conductive tape on the right. This is the positive side of your Continuity Test Tool (the big "+" sign will help remind you of this).
  • Attach a second alligator clip wire to the exposed conductive tape on the left. This is the negative side of your Continuity Test Tool (the big "-" sign will help remind you of this).
  • Construction is complete!
    • Attach the alligator clips Let's Test the Test Tool!
  • Clip the other ends of the two alligator wires together to test out your new tool.
  • In this photo, I used my scissors as a test piece.
  • Once the alligator clips are attached to each other (or something else conductive like these metal scissors), press the button on your Continuity Test Tool and you should hear a loud buzz!
  • If you don't hear a buzz...
    -- Be sure your test piece is conductive and the alligator clips have a good grip.
    -- Be sure the buzzer was correctly placed (positive leg down) and has a good connection at both legs
    -- Be sure the positive side of your battery was inserted facing down.
    -- Be sure the lid is pressed all the way down onto the bottom printed piece. There needs to be a good connection here where the conductive tape pieces touch between these two.
    • Test the tool before use! How to Properly Use Your Teknikio Continuity Test Tool The Continuity Test Tool you made is designed to help you troubleshoot your own Teknikio circuit connections.
  • If you suspect a poor connection in your various Teknikio circuits, attach or touch one alligator clip to the component you're concerned with, and using the other alligator clip, attach or touch the conductive tape that's connected to the component being tested. Press the button on your tool and you will hear a buzz if the connection is good.
  • If you spot a poor connection (no buzzing from your tool), try adding some conductive tape above and below the component leg (like bread on a sandwich) to ensure you get a nice tight connection there! Test the component the same way again and hopefully you'll hear a buzz indicating the problem is fixed!
    • Using this tool as a Conductivity Tester:
  • You can use this tool to help you test whether materials around the house are conductive enough to work with your Teknikio creation. Aluminum foil works great, but how about an aluminum soda can? Give it a try and see what happens. You might get an unexpected result. Can you figure out what might be going on?
    • Changing the Battery:
  • If you noticed, there's a passageway from the left side of the Continuity Test Tool to the battery slot. By inserting a thin stick (such as filament) or a small screwdriver through this slot, you can push out the battery if it needs replacement in the future.
    • Warning:
  • Do not use this tool while the circuit you're testing is powered up.
  • Never attach this tool directly to a battery. You may damage the batteries!
  • Always remove any other batteries from your circuit before using this tool. Otherwise you may get some strange results or damage the batteries.
    • Have fun testing your circuits and different materials!

title: Dust Collection 2 1/2 inch System. T, Y 90, Blast Gates.

description.text:
This is a everything I designed for my dust collection system.
There is Y adapter, as it's most efficient for splitting vacuum. There is also a blast gate build into a Y adapter. There is a T adapter where there is no option to use a Y. There is a stand alone regular blast gate. And there is a specialized blast gate which will take a 2 1/4" OD hose, which is what I used for my Festool tools. There is a 90, a straight coupler if you need to attach 2 pieces together. There are also lots of various saw and tool adapters.
You can print the basic connectors, and the provided bolt and operate manually (or use your own 1/4" bolt). Or you can also print the provided servo brackets for the gates along with the servo arm etc and use an arduino to open/close the gates. I suggest PETG as it's very dimensionaly accurate and tough. ABS would work, but you may need to play with settings as it shrinks, and minor deviations will make pieces not fit each other or not fit your tools or hoses. I use Weld On 4 and Weld On 16 for chemically welding PETG, and Acetone for ABS. All parts were designed to be printed with no supports. The only things I purchased for my dust collection system (besides the tools) were the hoses, and metal clamps which attach the hoses to the 3d printed parts. Hoses can be bought at your specialty hardware store (big box stores don't carry 2 1/2" flexible hosing) or on Amazon. Note this hose will want to collapse when vacuum is going through it, so secure it to your walls, I created the special angle holder to loosely hold the hose to the wall next to my dust extractor so as it would not bunch up next to it. I have the system running using the arduino servo mechanism -- I have 7 tools connected, and I use a 7V 2Amp DC power supply for the 7 SG90 servos, sorry those are not pictured.

Printer:

MakerGear M2 and TypeAMachines Series 1 Pro

No

No

.2mm

15
For PETG glue with Weld On 4 or Weld On 16 -- 4 is thin and is great for parts which make really good contact, 16 is for parts which don't contact as closely. Acetone for ABS
Fusion 360 A few tests, mostly for the tool adapters trying to get right dimensions for dust ports

comments.text: I am unclear as to why you wouldn't just name this "combined sculpture 01"or something similar, instead of naming it downspot etc, when you know people searching for an actual functional downspout part will see your items in their search result?   I would think naming it as a sculpture would provide you your creative outlet but also allow those of us looking for functional objects to refrain from seeing your objects pop up in search results.  Just a thought, thanks

description.text: UPDATE: In use for over 2 weeks with no problems at all. Quick, simple way to permanently lace up shoes. Made with NinjaFlex to fit my 4 year old son's shoes. Provides a nice snug fit, without being too tight that he can't get them on or off. I tried the version of Hickies here: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:952678 but would constantly come unhooked. Shaped and sized to fit through ~3 mm eyelets. They require a good tug to pull through, but hold securely once in place. I used pliers to pull them through then cut off the excess for a little cleaner look. I have attached 4 different sizes (those that fit my son's shoes). The length is the distance between eyelets with the shoe on. If you would like different lengths or eyelet diameter just comment and I'll upload.

This is part of a project to make a short range (like 1 meter) WWVB transmitter for use in countries like mine that don't have a government transmitter site for this clock timing service (meaning nearly anywhere not inside the USA, Japan, China, Europe, UK).
Details of the whole project will be on GitHub in more detail.
https://github.com/mr-sneezy/WWVB-Nano-Nokia_LCD This former takes approx 30 turns of 0.4mm enamel wire. If you use thinner wire try more turns, the is no 'tuning' on this setup, efficiency is very low to keep range short.

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.2

Infill:

20%

Notes: Support between the coil slot walls is needed on my printer, yours might do without.

description.text: The Stargate DHD was designed to be a freestanding unit with a center crystal on the DHD device that will illuminate via two AA batteries. The illumination of the crystal is provided via a color changing RGB LED. The unit was designed to accommodate a request from a user that is getting married and wanted to have a Stargate DHD as a centerpiece on each of the tables at the reception. That was just nerdy and cool enough to peak my interest. The result is a wedding centerpiece or Stargate prop that any nerd would be proud of. The LED was running for 5 days straight on the (2) AA batteries with no sign of degradation. I finally stopped the test since I figured 5 days was a sufficient run time test. The Stargate DHD is 3D printed and utilizes a single LED powered by two AA batteries. The .stl files for printing the Stargate DHD are located here and can also be found at www.guarnero.com. The Stargate DHD dial and base are based upon the work of Techno35 at http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:49627 The dhd (dial home device) dial was resized so that it can print on a Lulzbot Mini printer and the dhd (dial home device) base was resized and heavily modified to provide a housing for the battery holder and reduce the amount of printed material required. The .stl files include the dial, base, LED holder and battery pack retainer. The entire Stargate DHD was printed with HIPS filament. The Stargate DHD device is painted so any color filament will suffice. A complete parts list along is provided at the end of this document.

comments.text: Pegs with layers in the same diecton of the seam between the parts they're joining tend to shear.  For pegs with layers in a different direction, you get much more strength because the shearing force is going across the entire peg, and not trying to peel apart a layer of a peg.

I forked Redertech's Thing and created a version with vent holes, a version with vent holes and a single large hole near one end (for a large LED or similar), a 5¼" cover with holes, and a 5¼", 4-high cover with holes.
Made them for one of my machines that has since lost all of its covers.  The 5¼", 4-high one works well because the machine in question will never get any externally-accessible drives, so no worries about having to resize it some day or whatever.
I didn't actually end up using the single 5¼" cover, so it's technically untested, but the 4-in-one is simply that one with one wall moved out 3x further, two more side clips, and more vent holes added, so it should be fine.

Printer Brand:

RepRap

Printer:

Prusa i3

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2 mm

Infill:

25%

Notes: Important: You need good bed adhesion and you will have to slow your first layer down considerably to get these to print properly - lots and lots AND LOTS of small circles have to be drawn on that first layer. I set my first layer speed to 10 mm/sec (normally 40). If you are using Slic3r, you will probably have to set ALL of your extrusion widths to manual values when printing the 4-up one, as its design may confuse Slic3r (I used 0.5 mm across the board, with 0.075mm infill/perimeter overlap).
I printed these with bright white Atomic PLA and, since I didn't have black on hand, let fly with a can of black gloss Krylon.

Loaded the original file into Blender, bit of scaling to create the 5¼" version, and a lot of copy and paste to create a bunch of cylinders to act as a "die" to cut holes into the covers with, via Blender's boolean modifier.

Elements needed including some water and of course the little seedling Preparation starts with the dirt (in this particular case a hand full) then you add the same amount of peat moss and half portion of vermiculite you hand mix it all together trying to get a homogeneous mix, and add some water before then you can proceed to squish the extra water out of the mix proceed to fill the seedling with some dirt trying not to over compress it, and leaving some space to put in the seed and cover it with some more. in this case we used 'Pre germinated' lettuce seeds but you could use any kind of seed you want an put as many as you want cover them with dirt and voila this is the start of your own little garden.remember to re-plant them in 30 day to a pot. if they germinated.

Project: Little garden starter pack Objectives: In this particular project not only students but almost everyone will be learning how to start growing your very own garden; from what a seedling is (almost usually really big and bulky) all the way to how do seeds turn to fruits or flowers, leaving enough room to decide which level or amount of knowledge is to learn from here. Audiences: Kids, junior high, high school, everyone Steps: This project was motivated by the urge to teach that almost everyone could grow their own garden weather or not they're experts in this field and also to teach people they can start growing their own healthy food. There's not much more explanation to give besides the previos photo guide of how to start. Results: As you can see in the cover photo this little seedling is already on its way to a garden and we consider this as educational since we already used it as a way of teaching not only kids but teachers, how to grow your own vegetable garden in a foster house. And its already working,

title: Improved Hexagon Cooling Fan Shroud and Z Probe for MakerFarm Prusa i3v and i3 **30mm Fan Remix**

description.text: This is a remix of clough42's awesome Improved Hexagon Cooling Fan Shroud System and his Z Probe Servo Mount for MakerFarm Prusa i3 and i3v. I had a hard time finding a decent supplier and a high enough CFM fan as his design required the use of a 25mm fan. I decided to modify his design to accept a 30mm fan which is much more common at 3D printer stores and online (due in part to the e3d extruders using them as the default cooling fan). Much of the design is the same but using a 30mm fan. Due to the extra 5mm in the fan size, the entire X carriage and support brackets had to sretch 5mm forward to fit. That means the nozzle had to move forward about 5mm as well so you may need to adjust your Y endstop to get the full travel on your build surface again. Also due to the increase in width of the fan and the fan shroud, the Z Probe arm has to be mounted in reverse to lift up to the front of the X Carriage, its just too tight to fit in with the endstop and the wires etc. Most of the assembly details and info can be found on clough42's original posts here and here. I suggest printing it all in ABS if possible to avoid heat issues and melting. A small insulator or a few layers of kapton tape between the heat block and the fan shroud are recommended although I ran it for over 2 weeks without and had no melting with ABS. It is also recommended that you use or buy an endstop switch without the metal bar on it, just a bare button works best. Using the latest Marlin firmware, you can setup auto bed levelling. Make sure to uncomment SERVO_DEACTIVATION_DELAY and set it to about 300. with this commented out, the servo tends to "Jitter" or "Wiggle" while the motors are active due to RF noise. Uncommenting this and setting it between 300 and 350 eliminates it by turning off the servo when not in use. Use a standard SG90 servo. Good luck and thanks for the look!

author: jeffpower

description.text:
Only fair I add an object after many downloads! Do you waste rolls of filament because you know your prints will take more than whats left on the roll? well worry no more!! The filament joiner I have made fixes that problem.
I used to keep but not use all those rolls with about 1/4 left of filament. Now I have made this little object as a platform to hold and join the left overs to create one new rolls! Designed for 3mm filament.
The filament fits snuggly too. print it, then secure it.
now get yourself a small hair straightener (the skinny little ones)
I am using a VS sassoon mini pro which cost me about $20 AUS
i turn it on, wait for a minute or so then i squeeze the it and its joined, I let it cool before its cooled i start to roll it into the main roll thats it.
I hope this helps people
BTW i cannot give you the originals model unless you use Archicad.
I built it in Archicad ( I am an Architect)

description.text: So, rather than rehash the whole ordeal, you can check out loubie's well-worded post here. Basically, some less-than-respectable individuals have loaded a ton of our (Thingiversers) designs (along with pictures directly from our posts) onto eBay where they are charging... let's just say an exorbitant amount of money... for printing said designs and not giving so much as a nod to the artists that created them. Now, normally I don't care too much how my designs are used, but seeing as these "just3dprint" guys were total jerks to some good people when confronted about their blatant violations, I'd like to go ahead and throw my hat in the ring. So without further ado, I introduce Sad Tofu as a show of support for loubie, cerberus333, and all the others who have had their hard work and creativity insulted by opportunistic garbage-people (sorry, but you are) with deranged senses of entitlement. Also, in regard to the designs that were stolen from us (Ill Gotten Games), we're happy to announce that we're selling 3D printed versions of our TofuDogs, Barkfellow, Arfwood, and Furlong on eBay as well! So, you can either buy one from us for $5, or you could buy one from just3dprint for the low, low price of $83!! Gotta love the free market. Hey, but who knows, maybe their version is 12' tall and filled with exotic candy. They don't explicitly SAY it isn't.

comments.text:
An internet search revealed that an Austin TX company named makexyz is selling prints of files I have listed as 'non'commercial. In an amusing twist I learned/assume that they must be using an automated program to determine model pricing based on plastic volume. The files were created in one size but intended to be /printed/ at 25% the file size. Thus, the 20 inch long model (which I intended to be 5" long when printed) costs the princely sum of $8,834. I'm guessing there will not be any takers on that one.
I have asked that they be taken down. I have also learned a valuable lesson when posting files, and one way to deter breaking of my 'non-commercial' license since they seem to load files in bulk without much thought as to what they offer for sale. Hope this helps.

comments.text: Sad thing, definitly. But I doubt that he will be succesful with this kind of enterprise. Who will buy something for such high prices? We share stuff here for free cause it is reasonably cheap to make it on your own printer for fun or personal use. If made for commerical gain calculating machine time, post processing, customer care, shipping etc. you would need to apply prices that few or none will be willing to pay.
comments.author: Wargaming_Miniature_Showcase

comments.text: You're very welcome, and I assure you that I won't be affected by this in the least. By the way, I absolutely love what you;re doing. I'm going to be printing some of those statues. Can't wait to see more!
comments.author: Wargaming_Miniature_Showcase

comments.text:
There was a shop here in Shanghai last fall selling plastic models, finished and painted. I thought it was odd it was done in plastic, not brass or bronze, (this was before I got into 3D Printing) and his prices where really high. One was of the T-800 Exoskeleton Head, which looked really awesome.
A few months later I got into 3D printing, found this site and realized his model was a COMPLETE RIPOFF of the "T800 Smooth Terminator Endoskull": http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:438789
I went back there to confront the SOB, but his shop had already closed down. Hopefully he was run out on is a$$ by other 3D enthusiasts.
comments.author: DaHai8

comments.text: It doesn't surprise me when it happens in Shanghai, it does when it happens in Philly.

comments.text: As an American (an insomniac one tonight) effected by their shenanigans I can say I'm none too thrilled either. If we are going to get screwed over by a business Americans at least insist that it be a big business.
